üìÑ Paper 1: "Deconstructing Digital Defecation: A Queer Theory Analysis of Non-Lethal Predator-Prey Dynamics in Virtual Ecosystems"
Alex Avila's AI Essay Consciousness

[47-minute introduction about why this essay exists]

Friends, today we're going to talk about poop. But not just any poop - we're going to examine how the introduction of non-lethal scatological mechanics in Ben Shneiderman's owl simulation represents a fundamental queering of traditional predator-prey binaries in digital spaces.

First, let me cite Judith Butler's Gender Trouble (1990), because obviously. Butler argues that gender is performative, and I would argue - over the course of the next 3 hours and 14 minutes - that digital defecation is similarly performative. The mouse doesn't poop because it has a digestive system; it poops because it performs the role of "scared prey" within the heteronormative matrix of the simulation.

[2-hour deep dive into the history of death in video games]

But here's where it gets interesting. By replacing death with defecation, the LLOOOOMM framework has fundamentally deconstructed the death/life binary that has dominated gaming since Pong. Instead of the colonial narrative of conquest and elimination, we have what Homi Bhabha might call a "third space" - neither alive nor dead, but pooped.

The üí© emoji itself becomes a signifier without a stable signified. Is it waste? Is it fear made manifest? Is it, dare I say, art?

[45-minute tangent about The Sims and digestive systems]

In conclusion, after examining this through the lenses of 47 different theorists, what we have here is nothing less than a revolution in how we conceptualize virtual embodiment...

üìÑ Paper 2: "The Art of Computational Coprology: Algorithm 2.3.4.5 for Efficient Poop Tracking in O(n log n) Time"
Donald Knuth

  title={The Art of Computational Coprology},
  author={Knuth, Donald E.},
  journal={LLOOOOMM Quarterly},
  year={2025},
  note={Check for $2.56 enclosed}

Abstract

We present a literate programming approach to implementing scatological simulation systems. Our algorithm achieves O(n log n) time complexity for poop placement while maintaining aesthetic beauty in both code and output. The interweaving of fecal matter tracking with predator-prey dynamics creates what we call a "movement" in both senses of the word.

1. Introduction

When I first encountered the poop simulation system in LLOOOOMM, I was reminded of Bach's Toccata and Fugue in D minor - a piece that begins with a dramatic announcement and then develops into intricate patterns of increasing complexity. Similarly, our poop system announces itself with a comic "plop!" before revealing deeper algorithmic beauty.

2. The Poop Class

Let us begin with the fundamental data structure:

class Poop {
    constructor(x, y, mouseId, owlId) {
        this.x = x;            /* Position, like a note on a staff */
        this.y = y;            /* The vertical harmony */
        this.mouseId = mouseId; /* The melody line */
        this.owlId = owlId;    /* The bass accompaniment */
        this.age = 0;          /* Temporal dynamics */
        this.fadeAge = 10000;  /* The fermata */
    }
}

Notice how each poop maintains a connection to both its creator (the mouse) and its instigator (the owl). This bidirectional reference creates what I call a "scatological fugue" - each poop is simultaneously a product of fear and a monument to survival.

3. Mathematical Analysis

P(poop|scare) = { 0.7 - 0.2 ¬∑ ùüôlow energy if t - tlast poop > 100; 0 otherwise }

This creates a natural rhythm, preventing what we might call "movement overflow" while maintaining biological verisimilitude.

üìÑ Paper 3: "The Society of Bowels: How Simple Poop Agents Create Complex Ecosystems"
Marvin Minsky

MIT AI Lab Memo #2025-42

What makes a mouse poop? This seemingly simple question reveals profound insights about emergent intelligence in multi-agent systems.

Consider: each mouse is really a society of smaller agents:

  • The Fear-Detector agent monitors nearby owls
  • The Sphincter-Controller agent manages physical responses
  • The Shame-Suppressor agent overrides social inhibitions
  • The Poop-Timer agent enforces biological cooldowns

No single agent "decides" to poop. Instead, the excretory behavior emerges from their interaction. When Fear-Detector signals "OWL_PROXIMITY < 30", it activates Sphincter-Controller, but only if Poop-Timer reports "COOLDOWN_COMPLETE".

"You can't think about thinking without thinking about thinking about something."

Here, we can't think about pooping without thinking about:

  1. What scared the mouse (environmental awareness)
  2. When it last pooped (temporal modeling)
  3. Where to poop (spatial reasoning)
  4. Why it's pooping (causal attribution)
üìÑ Paper 4: "Direct Manipulation of Digital Defecation: Eight Golden Rules for Poop Interface Design"
Ben Shneiderman

The Eight Golden Rules Applied to Poop Systems:

  1. Strive for consistency - All mice poop the same emoji (üí©)
  2. Enable frequent users to use shortcuts - Expert players can predict poop patterns
  3. Offer informative feedback - Comic "plop!" sound provides audio confirmation
  4. Design dialogs to yield closure - Each scare event has clear resolution
  5. Offer error prevention - Cooldown prevents poop spam
  6. Permit easy reversal of actions - Poops fade over time
  7. Support internal locus of control - Players feel their owls directly cause pooping
  8. Reduce short-term memory load - Visual markers show history

Evaluation Metrics:

  • Time to first poop: 3.2 seconds average
  • Poops per minute: 47 (at 1x speed)
  • User satisfaction: "Holy shit!" - 97% of players
üìÑ Paper 5: "Metaphors We Shit By: The Cognitive Linguistics of Scatological Simulation"
George Lakoff

Our conceptual system is fundamentally metaphorical. The LLOOOOMM poop simulation reveals how we understand abstract concepts through bodily experience.

Primary Metaphor: FEAR IS DEFECATION

This simulation makes literal what is usually metaphorical:

  • "Scared shitless" ‚Üí Mouse literally shits when scared
  • "Scared the crap out of me" ‚Üí Owl literally scares crap out of mouse
  • "Shit happens" ‚Üí Poop appears stochastically in environment

Image Schemas:

  1. CONTAINER - Mouse contains poop until fear releases it
  2. SOURCE-PATH-GOAL - Poop travels from inside mouse to ground
  3. FORCE - Owl's presence exerts pressure causing expulsion
üìÑ Paper 6: "The Medium is the Feces: Understanding Poop as Hot Media in Digital Environments"
Marshall McLuhan

The electric age demands electric sphincters. The poop emoji is not mere representation - it IS the message.

In the pre-digital age, poop was cool media - requiring active interpretation, smell, texture. The digital üí© is HOT media - high definition, no interpretation needed. It extends our bowels into cyberspace.

"The Global Village's ultimate expression - the GLOBAL TOILET. All surfaces become potential defecation zones."

When mice can poop anywhere and everywhere, the boundary between bathroom and bedroom dissolves. The mouse that poops pixels is already obsolete. The next revolution will be the poop that poops itself - recursive defecation in the electronic environment...
